summary.seg: This small octavo manuscript contains the 16th-century Latin translation of Plutarch's essay Περὶ ἀδολεσχίας (De garrulitate, entitled De futili loquacitate) by John Christopherson (d. 1558), Master of Trinity College, Cambridge in 1553 and bishop of Chichester in 1557. The translation is preceded by a dedication epistle to Princess Mary Tudor Mary I., Queen of England 1516-1558 , while her brother Edward VI was king, and followed by a copy of the same text in Greek.
The manuscript is bound with CUL Dd.6.55, a copy, dated 1454, on parchment and paper, of the Quadriga Spirituale by Nicholas of Osimo (d. 1453) Nicholas, of Osimo, -1453 , in Italian.

msItem.title: Title page
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Plutarchi Chaeronei philosophi libellus de futili loquacitate à Graeco in Latinum per Ioannem Christofersonum conversus

msItem.author: Christopherson, John, -1558
msItem.title: Dedicatory epistle to Mary Tudor
msItem.rubric: f. 2r Honoratissimae illustrissimaeque Principi D. Mariae Regiae Maiestatis Sorori Ioannes Christofersonus perpetuam optat felicitatem
msItem.incipit: f. 2r Non sum nescius, Princeps illustrissima
msItem.explicit: f. 9v et me, quod mihi solum in optatis erat, cumulate certe este consecutum, existimabo. Vale. Tuae celsitudinis studiosissimus Ioannes Christofersonus

msItem.author: Plutarch
msItem.title: On Talkativeness
msItem.rubric: f. 10r Plutarchi Chaeronei Philosophi de futili loquacitate libellus
msItem.incipit: f. 10r Ardua plane et difficili est illa quidem curatio
msItem.explicit: f. 51r ut ait Hippocrates, sed dolore etiam caretet molestia. Finis

msItem.author: Plutarch
msItem.title: Περὶ ἀδολεσχίας (Moralia 35 = Plan. 14)
De garrulitate
msItem.rubric: f. 52r ΠΛΟΥΤΑΡΧΟΥ ΧΑΙΡΩΝΕΩΣ περὶ ἀδολεσχίας βιβλίον
msItem.explicit: f. 82v ὥς φησιν Ἱπποκράτης , ἀλλὰ καὶ ἄλυπον καὶ ἀνώδυνον

support.material: Western paper, folded in octavo. Watermarks barely visible in the gutter.

supportDesc.foliation: i-iii + 1-83 + [iv-v]. Modern foliation in pencil in Arabic numerals in the top right-hand corner, recto. (Dd.6.55 consists of iii + 118 folios; the foliation starts again with Dd.6.56).

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 10 quaternions, a single leaf and a bifolium. Quire 1 starts from f. 2, as f. 1 probably served as endleaf before the manuscript was bound together with Dd.6.55.
Henry Bradshaw Bradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886 added the bifolium signatures and a general note on collation on the pastedown at the end.

signatures.p: Modern quire signatures by Henry Bradshaw in pencil in the lower right-hand corner of the rectos.

supportDesc.condition: In general good condition; folios are yellowed by time and stained.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 2r-82v: A single column of 17 or 18 lines. Written space 100 65

handNote.p: The Greek text is written in a minuscule script by a practiced western scholar's hand, with persistent effort made towards aesthetic accuracy, and probably derived from printed models. The script is characterized by different capital forms, enlarged letters and marked oblique strokes, especially in delta.

binding.p: Binding in quarter with marbled paper and leather over couched-laminate boards.
The classmarks are tooled in gold on the spine.

history.origin: Because of the dedicatory epistle in which Mary Tudor is addressed as the king's sister, the manuscript can be dated between Edward VI's accession in 1547 and Mary's in 1553.

recordHist.source: Description (2019) draws on A catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, vol. 1, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1856, p. 309.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

monogr.title: A catalogue of the manuscripts preserved in the library of the University of Cambridge

analytic.title: How to Hold Your Tongue: John Christopherson’s Plutarch and the Mid-Tudor Politics of Catholic Humanism

monogr.title: Canadian Review of Comparative Literature / Revue Canadienne de Littérature Comparée
